page.title: 02HISTORY - CHIGNALS
page.content: There have been traces of IRON AGE found in ditches, and there is a ROMAN Villa which can be seen from the air. The name of the village has been changed over the years, from Chikehale in 1179 to Chignall today. Dyers Hall which was built in 1279 was demolished in recent years. In the 16th Century Great Newarks and Mashbury Hall were built. Mashbury Hall originally being called Marshbury Hall. The Gatehouse was given to Richard Gates by Henry VIII. In the 17th Century the public house called 'The Fox' and 'Fuddlers Hall', formerly 'Mount Pleasant Farm' were built. In 1842 the United Reformed Church was opened. In 1863 the village school of Chignal Smealy was built to house 100 children,this closed in the 1950's. In 1890 the Salvation Army Hall opened.
